captions.text:
I'm sorry.
I can explain.

Explain how you forgot
to invite us to your party?

Janis, I cannot stop this car.
I have a curfew.

You know I couldn't invite you.
I had to pretend to be plastic.

Hey, buddy, you're not
pretending anymore.
You're plastic.
Cold, shiny, hard plastic.

Daniel:
Curfew, 1 a.M. It is now 1:10.

Did you have
an awesome time?

Did you drink awesome shooters
and listen to awesome music,
And then just sit around

And soak up
each other's awesomeness?

You know what? You're the one
who made me like this

So you could use me
for your eighth-grade revenge.

God! See, at least me and
regina george know we're mean.

You try to act
like you're so innocent.

Like,
"oh, I used to live in africa

With all the little birdies
and the little monkeys."

You know what?
It's not my fault

You're in love with me
or something!

What?!
Oh, no she did not!

See? That is the thing
with you plastics.

You think that everybody
is in love with you,

When actually,
everybody hates you.

Like aaron samuels,
for example.

He broke up with regina
and guess what.
He still doesn't want you.

So why are you still
messing with regina, cady?
I'll tell you why.
Because you are a mean girl!
You're a bitch!

Here. You can have this.
It won a prize.

And I want
my pink shirt back!

I want
my pink shirt back!
( <i>subdued african theme plays</i> )
Hon, slow down.

title: Mean Girls (6/10) Movie CLIP - You're Plastic (2004) HD

comments.text:
I like Janis as a character, but I think she was too harsh when she called 
Cady a bitch. I mean, I don't remember Cady doing anything mean to Janis in 
the movie, so why call her a bitch? I agree that Cady was becoming a 
plastic and she wasn't pretending anymore, but when you hang out with 
certain people, their ways start to rub off on you.﻿
comments.author: ShanyLiyah Jennifer

comments.text:
This scene was literally the apex of Lindsay Lohan's acting abilities. She 
actually started crying for real at the end there. WTF happened?﻿

comments.author: Kat Morgan

comments.text:
Guys, you need to remember that Janice never intended to completely destroy 
Regina's life by using Cady, all she asked was that they know the things 
that the plastics said/did so they could laugh at it later. Yes, that was 
still petty in it's own way, but if you compare it to other things it's not 
really a big deal. Not only that, but Janice did say herself that she knows 
she's mean, she acknowledges it while Cady had become rather dishonest 
throughout the movie, flipping from one side to the other. It wasn't until 
the whole fiasco with Regina taking Aaron back right in front of Cady that 
Janice came up with her plans, and was more out of trying to help Cady and 
let Regina get what was coming to her and not out of middle school revenge. 
And even then, Cady had started to become increasingly obsessed on her own, 
trying harder to sabotage them on nights where Janice didn't have anything 
planned. It should also be realized that Regina had ruined Janice's life 
first out of her own arrogance, so you can't really blame her for being 
angry.
However, I DO believe that Janice was still being too hard on her in this 
scene. While Cady had essentially become the new Regina, lied about a few 
things, and needed some scolding, another thing to realize is that before 
this Cady had been home-schooled. Of course she wouldn't have really known 
exactly what to do in her situation and probably more just wanted to fit 
in, flipping from side to side on the friendship bar. Being the new kid in 
a high school is already stressful enough as it is, but even more so when 
you've never been to a high school at ALL in the past.
However, these are just my opinions and thoughts, everyone has the right to 
think what they want, I am simply here stating my own opinion.﻿

Personally I have never felt Janis was one of the "good ones" in this

of Cady to get her revenge, then she humilliate both Candy and Regina ( 
This one deservely so) at the "apologies reunion" and was acting 
indignantly cause Cady ditch her for the girls who despite being bitchy, 
were friendly and accepting of her. I personally saw Cady as acting out of 
a survival point of view. Janis was just a spiteful bitch(Though funny.)
Edit: I seriously believe if Janis would have not been humilliated by 
Regina, she would have been A "cold, shining plastic".﻿

comments.text:
Janis may not be any better than Regina but at least she knows it. She's 
not denying it. And she does genuinely see Cady as a friend, so she has a 
right to be upset that Cady's suddenly blowing her off for the Plastics. 
It's a very people-pleasing dishonest attitude that Cady's exhibiting and 
she's not being honest with people. She needs to either be friends with 
Janis or be friends with the Plastics, but she can't have both. And I think 
that's basically what Janis is trying to say here.﻿
comments.author: MarryXMeXBuryXMe

comments.text:
Sorry, I have no sympathy for Janis. Your friends don't use you! Janis used 
Cady from day one to get back at Regina. So, while Cady did make her own 
choices, Janice set her on that path to begin with after that first day in 
the cafeteria. Janis was only upset because it came back to bite her in the 
butt. She set Cady on that path and then acted surprised when Cady got 
sucked into that life. Janis may "know she is mean", but she never 
apologized for using Cady to get her revenge.

comments.text:
People can say whatever they want to say about Janice but she's still my 
favourite character in the whole movie. She did admit to what she did, and 
don't tell me that Regina didn't have it coming, she's the one who made up 
a rumour about her best friend out of arrogance.  Besides, how do we know 
that what Regina said was true?  How do we know that what really happened 
was that Regina's 'boyfriend' from 8th grade actually liked Regina? What if 
he actually liked Janice and Regina made up that rumour because she was 
jealous? Think about it....he's moved, he can't give his side of the story 
and when Cady said she liked Aaron, Regina told him that she was crazily 
obsessed with him and then stole him back and lied to Cady about it. And 
all Janice asked Cady to do was to tell her stuff so they could make fun of 
her, not to go the full way like that. I'm just saying. ﻿

comments.author: yenelly tejada

comments.text:
It's been years since I saw this movie, but I loved how everyone was a 
hypocrite and a "mean girl." I absolutely abhorred the stupid happy ending, 
where everyone learned a lesson and became friends. That was when the 
movies stopped being realistic, relatable, and interesting.﻿
comments.author: YT Cyberpunk

comments.text:
+YT Cyberpunk It would be a crappy ending if you're thinking of Cady's life 
getting ruined after all the shit she's been through. There wouldn't be a 
proper resoulution if in the end, she never learned the lesson. The lesson 
was to break the "rules" of the girl world ("If the limit never approaches 
anything, the limit does not exist") and actually live without the 
"important" things in the girl world (the breaking the tiara scene). That's 
the only way to live freely. Plus, it's not like everyone forgave each 
other and everything's in good form. That's pretty clear when we see the 
junior plastics in the end. Just because Cady reunited with her friends and 
the plastics finally broke up doesn't mean that everyone felt the same way. 
We may never know....
comments.author: 21minute

comments.text:
Plenty of stories have lessons and resolutions without happy endings. The 
ending of "Mean Girls" was unrepeatable because of how everyone learned 
their lesson at the same time, and so quickly, and all became friends just 
like that. Up until then, I was liking the movie for how it portrayed what 
a dog-eat-dog world high school can be. Then suddenly, boom, a 
happy-go-lucky ending.

It's like if "Les Mis" ended with Javert and Val Jon hugging and making up, 
and the French government apologizing to the peasants and rebuilding France 
into a Utopia.
comments.author: YT Cyberpunk

comments.text:
Well, you can't expect everyone to be the same after the ending. What's the 
point of the movie if no one learned their lesson in the end? When it comes 
to telling a story, there has to be an outcome and a resolution. Otherwise, 
it would be just a stupid movie about bitches biting each others' asses 
from start to end. And how is learning a life lesson unrealistic and 
unrelatable?
comments.author: 21minute

comments.text:
+trysometruth
Wow, I had a MAJOR typo. I meant to say "the movie" not "the movies."
comments.author: YT Cyberpunk

comments.text:
Movies didn't stop being realistic in 2004 because Mean Girls came out.  
Yeesh.  Tina Fey adapted the book "Queen Bees and Wannabes: Helping Your 
Daughter Survive Cliques, Gossip, Boyfriends, and Other Realities of 
Adolescence" in making this movie.  She largely completely invented the 
narrative of the movie because the book didn't really have a story arc.  
But Fey wanted to be true to the book in that its point was to try to help 
navigate through the pettiness.  That's why she included the "workshop" 
scene in the gym.  They all felt it was worthwhile to show the characters 
growing out of the worst in themselves.
comments.author: trysometruth

comments.text:
Without typing out a SUPER long paragraph, I'm gonna try to keep it 
simple.  Both Cady and Janis are in the wrong, yet both are right.  And do 
remember that in the middle of the conflict things start to stir up, so not 
likely is ANYONE fully right, because that the end of the movie where they 
all get up for confessions and do a trust fall, Janis confesses her whole 
plan of revenge on Regina by using Cady.﻿
comments.author: MegaAniLinkFan

comments.text:
Guys... let's not forget Regina turned everyone against, spread rumors 
about, and bullied Janis until she was forced to drop out of school.... 
Janis's rage and grudge was reasonable.﻿
comments.author: Izzy Grace

comments.text:
I myself (being a lesbian) experienced something similar, I was friends 
with this girl in high school whom was extremely popular and started 
telling everyone that I was gay, to the point where I left that school. 
Last year, the woman who spread the rumours and I caught up over coffee, 
she apologised for the things she did and I forgave her, still I could 
understand how someone would hold an everlasting grudge apron someone for 
doing this.

comments.author: Patrick Blake

comments.text:
You're right that Janis ain't no different than Regina, but she's also 
right to title "bitch" to Cady...
She furiously complaints to Cady because Cady refused her invitation to see 
her art work with the excuse that she had to go out with her parents, then 
she accidently caught Cady is having a party without inviting her and 
Damian...
In my opinion, besides also having her personal 8th grade revenge, Janis 
thought that after she helped Cady "steal" all the 3 Regina's "properties" 
Cady is happily satisfied and thanked her later by willing to go out with 
her and Damian, but it turned out that Cady is still insisted her silent 
obsession on becoming Regina's "successor" because Cady thought that her 
crush, Aaron, could only fall in love with a popular-but-mean queen bee 
like Regina...
So the conclusion is, it's natural that Janis calls Cady a bitch because 
the house party proved that Cady prefers to be a popular mean queen bee by 
not inviting them than to be with them 
who-already-helped-her-getting-revenge-upon-Regina ONLY because she feels 
ashamed and afraid that her party friends and Aaron will be "disgusted" of 
her for being an unpopular nerd who hangs out with some of the "outcasts" 
like Janice and Damian...
And Janice's scold and "preach" seems to be really a perfect shock therapy 
for Cady that Cady finally realized her mistakes toward her, Damian and 
fellow schoolmates then decided to redeem herself as the only one who took 
the full blame over the Burn Book...
comments.author: Beatrix957

comments.text: Yeah, I was just saying Janis' point of view and how she wasn't a hypocrite.

she didn't have any reason for it. She was still planning for revenge.
